item.title: Introducing {twohundredfiftythings}
item.description: I decided to get a little wild with my Sunday, so I wrote a tiny R package! I also submitted it to CRAN. Its my first time submitting to CRAN, but I’m feeling hopeful! {twohundredfiftythings} is a tiny R package that allows the user to access Michael Sorkin’s list of things an architect should know. The list was originally published in “What Goes Up: The Rights and Wrongs to a City”.

item.title: Finding the perfect sock pattern with ravelRy
item.description: I am a knitter. Knitting is a calming, fulfilling practice that keep my hands busy and require just enough brain power to keep my mind from wandering too far. Over the past winter, I conquered my fear of making socks, and now I profess that I am a sock knitter. I made socks for Christmas gifts, and churned out four pairs during my evenings, bus commutes, long work meetings, lectures, coffee and tea shop visits (basically everywhere).

item.title: Minnesota Lakes
item.description: Sources DNR Hydrography Dataset National Wetland Inventory for Minnesota Lake Bathymetric Outlines, Contours, Vegetation, and DEM Lake Basin Morphology Impaired Waterbodies, Minnesota, 2018 Stream Routes - Major River Centerlines

item.title: Housing Density in US Cities
item.description: Since I got back from #rstudioconf, I’ve started to warm up to the idea of sharing my code, even if it isn’t perfect. There may be typos, the blog post may be short, but sharing my work is beneficial for the greater #rstats community, and supports open-source data science. So this belated post is inspired by Cities Start to Question an American Ideal: A House With a Yard on Every Lot, in which the NY Times examines residential zoning patterns in different cities.

item.title: Fisk's 'Mississippi River Meander' in R
item.description: Background Prep Data cleaning Explore geological ages and formations Wisconsin glaciation Context and inset map Finishing up Notes Data citation Background Those of us even mildly obsessed with maps will be familiar with Harold Fisk’s 1944 series documenting the historic travel of the Mississippi River in Mississippi River Alluvial Valley. In my house in college, filled with geography majors and map enthusiasts, we had a small print hung on the wall, and it was easy to start reading it, and end up standing there, just staring, for quite a while.

item.title: Visualizing mental health data with ggplot2
item.description: Export and download app data Clean and tidy Visualize moods over time with ggplot2 Custom styles October 2019 update now with gganimate! Inspiration and credits Things I love include data visualization, tutorials, and fighting mental illness stigma. This post combines them all! I made a pretty neat layout with plots and a map of my Location History a while back, and here I’ll walk through some of the data cleaning process and custom styling.
